learning_outcomes.description: comprehend and appreciate the law and regulatory processes applicable to international trade; particularly the relevance to sales contract law, international arbitration and international finance;
recognise legal problems associated with international trade; use legal reasoning in the analysis of such problems; and apply legal principles to solve such problems;
appreciate the business and social contexts in which international trade operates and is regulated; and
identify and appreciate aspects of international trade law and commerce that give rise to business, ethical and legal issues.

assessments.task_description:
1. The assignment question will be released in week 1.
  2. Length - No more than 2,000 words in length. There will be a 5% penalty for each 10% of part thereof for papers that exceed the word limit. A penalty will be levied at the rate of 10% of the marks available for the assessment item per day that the assessment is overdue. The date and time of submission will be deemed to be that noted on the electronic submission. Assessment submitted more than 7 days after the due date and time will receive zero marks.
  3. The student's name and number must appear at the top of the page.
  4. All authorities must be properly referenced and cited following the Australian Guide to Legal Citation (4th edition). When referencing internet sites include eg "Visited 23 March 2025". A complete bibliography must be included. Footnotes are not counted in the word count provided they are used as footnotes; that is for citations or perhaps as one-line comments.
  5. Students should seek to show that they can comprehend the material and present it accurately; analyse legislation and cases (where applicable); discern the principles and policies which underlie rules; produce critical review; and develop innovative answers to difficult cases.
  6. Technological failure is not a ground for the granting of an extension. Students preparing assignments on computers should ensure that programs are backed up.
  7. Students are expected to undertake original research themselves, using appropriate original sources (legislation and cases), textbooks, academic and professional journals and electronic information technology.
  8. Whilst students may use Artificial Intelligence (AI) and/or Machine Translation (MT) technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance. A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy. To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Assignments must be submitted electronically via the submission link on the course Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
Any written or printed material is permitted in the exam; it may also be annotated. Students are required to answer three compulsory essay or problem style questions.

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct Policy.
assessments.submission_guidelines: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.learning_period: Multiple weeksFrom Week 1 To Week 13(24 Feb - 01 Jun)
learning_activities.topic:
Lectures

The programme of lectures for the course is set out in the course learning guide. This is available from the course Blackboard site.

Lecture Topics are:

  1. Introduction - Incoterms 2020
  2. Private International Law
  3. International Sale of Goods
  4. Carriage of Goods
  5. International Commercial Arbitration
  6. Financing of International Imports and Exports

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04

learning_activities.topic:
Tutorials

There will be 6 tutorials throughout the semester covering the material from the previous week's lecture – in weeks 2, 4, 6, 8, 11, 13


Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
